title: 外人
background:
> It is precisely because I have experienced it myself that I can say this—the existence of a stepsister is merely that of an outsider.\
—Asamura Yuuta
description:
Yuuta and Saki sometimes meet each other at school. Due to being in different classes, they are mostly in different places during class time and only see each other when changing classrooms between classes.

Suisei High School has a total of $n-1$ class intervals in a day. During the $i$-th interval, Yuuta moves from the $y_i$-th floor to the $y_{i+1}$-th floor, and Saki moves from the $s_i$-th floor to the $s_{i+1}$-th floor. Assuming the class interval starts at time $i$ and ends at time $i+1$, their movements can be viewed as line segments from point $(i,y_i)$ to $(i+1,y_{i+1})$ and from $(i,s_i)$ to $(i+1,s_{i+1})$ on a plane with time $t$ as the horizontal axis and height $h$ as the vertical axis.

If they are at the same height at the same time, meaning if the two line segments mentioned above intersect, then they will see each other. They can meet on the stairs between floors, at the start, or at the end of the interval. That is, the intersection coordinates do not have to be integers and can be endpoints of the segments. Specifically, if Yuuta and Saki are on the same floor during a class, i.e., $y_i=s_i$, then they are considered to have seen each other during the $(i-1)$-th interval (if $i\ge2$) and the $i$-th interval (if $i\le n-1$).

They want to know how many intervals they will see each other in total today.
inputFormat:
The first line inputs an integer $n$ representing the number of class periods, with $n-1$ class intervals.

The second line inputs $n$ integers representing $y_1,\dots,y_n$.

The third line inputs $n$ integers representing $s_1,\dots,s_n$.
outputFormat: Output one line with an integer representing the number of intervals they meet.
hint:
#### Sample Explanation

During the first interval, Yuuta and Saki meet on the stairs between the $1$st and $2$nd floors;

During the second interval, they do not meet.

#### Data Range and Constraints

For $20\%$ of the data, $y_i,s_i\le2$.

For another $20\%$ of the data, all $y_i$ are equal.

For another $20\%$ of the data, all $s_i$ are equal.

For all data, $2\le n\le10$, $1\le y_i,s_i\le10$.

title: 磨合
background:
[This](https://www.luogu.com.cn/problem/U29089) is the English statement.\
But you can only submit your solution here.

> 「Being able to 'grind' like this is really a big help.」\
——绫濑沙季
description:
Yuuta and Saki encountered $n$ problems, with difficulties $d_1,\dots,d_n$.

They can solve the problems in any order. For the $i$-th problem they prepare to solve, the difficulty decreases by $1$ each time, and they need to spend $i$ seconds. When the difficulty is reduced to $0$, the problem is solved, and they can proceed to the next one.

If they are solving the $i$-th problem but the remaining time is less than $i$ seconds, they cannot continue solving the remaining problems, and the $i$-th problem is also not solved.

They want to know, given a total of $t$ seconds, what is the maximum number of problems they can solve. Since they may face many different scenarios, they will change $t$ multiple times for queries.
inputFormat:
The first line contains two integers $n,q$ representing the total number of problems and the number of queries.

The second line contains $n$ integers, representing $d_1,\dots,d_n$.

The next $q$ lines each contain an integer representing the total time $t$ for the query.
outputFormat: For each query, output one line with an integer representing the maximum number of problems that can be solved.
hint:
#### Sample Explanation

If $t=10$, then the first problem solved has difficulty $7$, the second has difficulty $1$, and the time spent is $1\times7+2\times1=9$ seconds. It can be proven that they cannot solve three problems.

If $t=16$, then the problems solved in order have difficulties $7,3,1$, and the time spent is $1\times7+2\times3+3\times1=16$ seconds.

#### Data Range and Constraints

**This problem uses bundled tests. The constraints and scores for each Subtask are as follows.**

| Subtask No. | $n\le$ | $q\le$ | $d_i\le$ | $t\le$ | Score | Dependencies |
| :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |
| $1$ | $10$ | $1$ | $10$ | $10^3$ | $13$ |  |
| $2$ | $10^3$ | $1$ | $10^3$ | $10^9$ | $24$ | $1$ |
| $3$ | $10^3$ | $10^6$ | $10^3$ | $10^9$ | $16$ | $1,2$ |
| $4$ | $10^6$ | $1$ | $10^3$ | $10^{16}$ | $16$ | $1,2$ |
| $5$ | $10^6$ | $10^6$ | $10^3$ | $10^{16}$ | $31$ | $1,2,3,4$ |

For all data, it is guaranteed that $1\le n,q\le10^6$, $1\le d_i\le10^3$, $0\le t\le10^{16}$.

title: 理解
background:
**The sample for this problem has been added. Please download it from the attachments. Among them, `sample2-4` respectively satisfy the special properties of Subtask 2-4.**

> "Asamura-san, for me..."\
"**You understand too deeply.**"\
——Shizuku Sasaki
description:
Shizuku is using the method recommended by Yuta to practice modern reading comprehension.

There are $n$ historical events, numbered from $1$ to $n$, where each historical event may have a predecessor event with a smaller number or may not have one. Formally, for event $i$, its predecessor event is denoted by $p_i$, satisfying $p_i<i$. If $p_i=0$, it means it has no predecessor event.

Shizuku has two ways to remember a historical event: recall and association. If she recalls, she can spend $r_u$ time to directly remember any historical event $u$; if she associates, she can choose any already remembered event $u$ and spend $t_v$ time to remember an event $v$ that satisfies $p_v=u$.

However, her brain capacity is limited, so she can remember at most $k$ events simultaneously. She can choose to forget any remembered event at any time, which does not cost any time. To prevent memory confusion, she will not remember any event she has forgotten again.

Now, she has $m$ reading comprehension questions. Solving the $i$-th question requires her to remember event $x_i$. She can immediately solve the $i$-th question when she remembers event $x_i$, and the time spent is ignored. She wants to know the minimum total time she needs to spend to solve all the questions.
inputFormat:
The first line of input contains an integer $T$ representing the number of test cases.

For each test case, the first line contains three integers $n,m,k$ representing the number of historical events, the number of reading questions, and the maximum number of events she can remember simultaneously.

The second line contains $n$ integers, representing $p_1,\dots,p_n$.

The third line contains $n$ integers, representing $r_1,\dots,r_n$.

The fourth line contains $n$ integers, representing $t_1,\dots,t_n$. It is guaranteed that $t_i=0$ when $p_i=0$.

The fifth line contains $m$ integers, representing $x_1,\dots,x_m$.
outputFormat: For each test case, output one line containing an integer, representing the minimum total time required to solve all the questions.
hint:
#### Sample Explanation

For the first test case, the relationship between historical events is as shown in the following figure:

![pic](https://cdn.luogu.com.cn/upload/image_hosting/70kj9xfv.png)

She can perform the following memory process:

| Step | Process | Time Spent | Remembered Events | Solved Questions |
| :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |
| $1$ | Recall event $1$ | $1$ | $\{1\}$ |  |
| $2$ | Associate event $3$ | $1$ | $\{1,3\}$ |  |
| $3$ | Associate event $5$ | $2$ | $\{1,3,5\}$ | $3$ |
| $4$ | Forget event $3$ | $0$ | $\{1,5\}$ |  |
| $5$ | Associate event $2$ | $1$ | $\{1,2,5\}$ | $1$ |
| $6$ | Forget event $2$ | $0$ | $\{1,5\}$ |  |
| $7$ | Recall event $4$ | $4$ | $\{1,4,5\}$ | $2$ |

Total time spent: $1+1+2+1+4=9$.

#### Data Range and Constraints

**This problem uses bundled tests. The constraints and scores for each Subtask are as follows.**

| Subtask No. | $n,m\le$ | Special Properties | Score | Dependencies |
| :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |
| $1$ | $10$ |  | $18$ |  |
| $2$ | $10^5$ | A | $18$ |  |
| $3$ | $10^5$ | B | $18$ |  |
| $4$ | $10^5$ | C | $18$ |  |
| $5$ | $10^5$ |  | $28$ | $1,2,3,4$ |

Special Property A: Guarantees $p_i=0$ or $p_i=i-1$;

Special Property B: Guarantees $p_i=\lfloor\frac i2\rfloor$;

Special Property C: Guarantees $p_i\le1$.

For all data, it is guaranteed that $1\le T\le5$, $1\le n,m\le10^5$, $1\le k\le10$, $0\le p_i<i$, $0\le r_i,t_i\le10^9$, $1\le x_i\le n$.

title: 回报
background:
> In my view, too many people are clearly me, yet it's me who should think about how to repay them properly.\
— Asakura Yota
description:
Yota needs to help Saki find suitable music for studying.

He found an album containing $n$ pieces of music, numbered from $1$ to $n$, each requiring $1$ minute to play. Saki has two courses, A and B, to study, each requiring $a$ and $b$ minutes respectively. To better assist her, Yota plans to rearrange the playback order of the music. Specifically, he needs to choose a permutation $p_1,\dots,p_n$ of length $n$ such that there exist two cycles $A$ and $B$ of lengths $a$ and $b$ respectively, and any element in $A$ is smaller than any element in $B$.

A cycle $C$ of length $k$ in the permutation is a sequence of distinct integers $c_1,\dots,c_k$ where $1\le c_1\le n$, $c_{i+1}=p_{c_i},i=1,\dots,k-1$, and $p_{c_k}=c_1$.

Yota wants to know how many such permutations $p$ satisfy the requirements. Since the answer might be very large, you only need to tell him the result modulo $998244353$.
inputFormat: The input consists of three integers $n$, $a$, and $b$.
outputFormat: Output a single integer representing the number of valid permutations modulo $998244353$.
hint:
#### Sample 1 Explanation

The valid permutations are $(2,1,3,4),(3,2,1,4),(1,3,2,4)$, totaling $3$.

#### Data Range and Constraints

**This problem uses bundled tests. The constraints and scores for each Subtask are as follows.**

| Subtask No. | $n\le$ | Special Property | Score | Dependencies |
| :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |
| $1$ | $10$ | Yes | $7$ |  |
| $2$ | $700$ | Yes | $10$ | $1$ |
| $3$ | $700$ | No | $20$ | $1,2$ |
| $4$ | $2000$ | Yes | $10$ | $1,2$ |
| $5$ | $2000$ | No | $30$ | $1,2,3,4$ |
| $6$ | $10^6$ | Yes | $20$ | $1,2,4$ |
| $7$ | $10^6$ | No | $3$ | $1,2,3,4,5,6$ |

Special Property: $\min(a,b)=1$.

For all data, $1\le n\le10^6$, $1\le a,b<a+b\le n$.

title: 报社天狗
background: Because Tianyi couldn't figure out how to write the lyrics for the new song, the protagonist of this problem is not Tianyi.
description:
The new issue of "Wenwen. News" is now on sale!

$n$ monsters are queuing up to buy "Wenwen. News", each numbered from $1$ to $n$. However, they are not buying "Wenwen. News" to read it, but to give a copy to every monster whose number is a multiple of their own (they may not keep one for themselves). In other words, for each monster from $1$ to $n$, the following process is performed: when the number of "Wenwen. News" on hand is sufficient, no purchase is made, and the copies are directly given away; when insufficient, they will first buy just enough copies from Wenwen, then proceed to give them away.

To maximize profits, Wenwen has devised a detailed pricing scheme for each monster. Specifically, the $i$-th monster will spend $a_i \times b_{j+1}$ to buy one more copy when they already have $j$ copies of "Wenwen. News", where $a$ and $b$ are two positive integer sequences starting from $1$ with a length of $10^6+1$.

Now, Wenwen needs a reasonable pricing scheme, and she decides to start adjusting from the initial state where all elements of $a$ and $b$ are $1$. Specifically, there are three types of operations:

- `1 x`: Query the total revenue Wenwen can get with the current $a$ and $b$ arrays when $n=x$. Since the result might be very large, you need to output the answer modulo $2^{32}$.
- `2 x y`: Adjust the $a$ array appropriately: set $a_x=y$.
- `3 x y`: Adjust the $b$ array appropriately: set $b_x=y$.

$\dag$: After verification, both quantifiers "only" and "individual" have appeared in usage. THBwiki shows that "one monster" matches significantly more often than "one individual monster", hence this problem uses "only" without any racial discrimination by the problem setter.
inputFormat:
The first line contains an integer $T$ representing the number of operations.

Lines $2$ to $T+1$ each contain $2$ or $3$ integers, representing an operation in the problem.
outputFormat: For each query, output an integer representing the profit modulo $2^{32}$.
hint:
### Sample Explanation

In the first query, $n=5$, all elements in both sequences are $1$. Monster $1$ buys $4$ copies of the newspaper, each contributing $1$ to the revenue, while other monsters do not buy any, resulting in a total revenue of $4$.

In the second query, $n=5$, $a_2=3$, $b_1=5$, with other elements in the sequences being $1$. Monster $1$ buys $4$ copies, with the first copy contributing $3$ and the next three copies each contributing $1$, resulting in a total revenue of $6$.

In the third query, $n=6$, $a_2=3$, $b_1=5$, with other elements being $1$. The process is as follows:

+ Monster $1$ needs to give a copy to every other monster but has none, so she buys $5$ copies. The first copy contributes $3$, and the next four copies each contribute $1$. Then she gives one copy to each other monster.

+ Monster $2$ needs to give copies to monsters $4$ and $6$ and has already received one copy from monster $1$. She buys one more copy, which contributes $5$.

+ Monster $3$ needs to give a copy to monster $6$ and has already received one from monster $1$, so she does not need to buy more.

+ Monsters $4$ to $6$ neither need to give away copies nor buy more.

The total revenue is $12$.

### Data Scale and Constraints

**This problem uses bundled tests.** You will only receive points for this subtask if you pass all test cases.

For $100\%$ of the data, $1 \leq T \leq 10^5$, $1 \leq x,n\leq 10^6$, $1\le y\le 10^9$.

For different subtasks, the constraints are as follows:

| Subtask ID | Special Properties | Points |
| :-----: | :----------------------------------: | :----: |
|    $1$    | No modification operations | $10$ |
|    $2$    | All $n$ in the first operation are equal | $20$ |
|    $3$    | $n,T \leq 10^5$ | $30$ |
|    $4$    | None | $40$ |

title: 破自行车
background:
One summer, the staff of Workshop 18071 collectively changed jobs. By the end of the year, Tianyi finally secured a collaboration in Workshop 40312. However... looking at the significant difference in workshop numbers, arriving on time for work was not an easy task.

At half past seven, the alarm rings, signaling the start of another early morning rush!
description:
The city where Tianyi lives resembles an infinite Manhattan grid. If the city map is placed on a plane Cartesian coordinate system, any integer point (x,y) represents a street intersection. Tianyi's home is at the intersection (0,0), and she needs to depart from here to reach the workplace intersection (a,b) as quickly as possible. Every minute, Tianyi can move from her current intersection (x,y) to (x+1,y), (x-1,y), (x,y+1), or (x,y-1).

How will Tianyi commute to work? She can use a very fast and unconventional bike! Riding it, Tianyi can instantly dash from (x,y) to one of four positions: (x+l,y), (x,y+l), (x-l,y), or (x,y-l), without spending any time. But to prevent the bike from breaking down, Tianyi can use it at most k times.

So, with the help of the bike, what is the minimum time Tianyi needs to travel from (0,0) to (a,b)?

Since the workplace often relocates, there are multiple test cases.
inputFormat:
The first line contains an integer T, indicating the number of test cases.

Following are T lines, each containing four integers a, b, k, l, representing the horizontal and vertical coordinates of the workplace intersection, the usage limit of the bike, and the bike's movement distance.
outputFormat: Output T lines, where the i-th line contains an integer representing the minimum time required to reach the workplace for the i-th test case.
hint:
### Sample Explanation:

We use > to represent dashing and → to represent walking.

For the first sample, one possible movement is: (0,0)>(2,0)→(3,0)→(4,0)→(4,1)>(4,3)>(4,5).

For the second sample, one possible movement is: (0,0)→(0,1)→(1,1).

For the third sample, one possible movement is: (0,0)>(0,8)>(8,8).

### Data Scale and Constraints

**This problem uses bundled tests.** You will only receive the score for this subtask if you pass all its test cases.

For 100% of the data, 1 ≤ T ≤ 10^5, 0 ≤ a,b,k,l ≤ 10^9.

For different subtasks, the constraints are as follows:

| Subtask No. | T | a,b,l | k | Special Properties | Subtask Score |
| :----------: | :----------: | :----------: | :----------: | :----------: | :----------: |
| 1 | ≤10^5 | ≤10^9 | =0 | None | 15 |
| 2 | ≤10 | ≤10 | ≤10 | None | 10 |
| 3 | ≤10 | ≤10^9 | ≤20 | None | 15 |
| 4 | ≤10 | ≤10^9 | ≤10^3 | None | 20 |
| 5 | ≤10^5 | ≤10^9 | ≤10^9 | a,b≤l | 15 |
| 6 | ≤10^5 | ≤10^9 | ≤10^9 | None | 25 |

title: 「FAOI-R9」函数大师
background:
As a computer technology expert, Ming Yue enjoys using a geometry board to draw images of various bizarre functions, such as $ y=\frac{x^x}{\sin x} $, $ y=\lfloor x^{\tan x} \rfloor $, $ y=\frac{x+x^3+x^5+x^7}{1+x^2+x^4+x^6} $. Some are continuous, some are discrete, and some look very strange. But as a math master who scored 99/100 in the middle school math exam, he confidently believes he can grasp the patterns of many functions.

So, Qing Feng gave him such a function.
description:
Qing Feng defines the function $ s(x)(x \in \mathbb{N^*}) $ to represent the sum of the digits of $ x $ in decimal representation, i.e.:

$$ s(x)=\sum_{i=0}^{+\infty}(\lfloor \frac{x}{10^i} \rfloor \bmod 10) $$
Qing Feng further defines $ S_k(x) (x\in \mathbb {N^*},k\in \mathbb{N}) $, satisfying:

$$ S_0(x) = x,S_k(x) = s(S_{k-1}(x)) $$

Qing Feng then defines $ f_k(x)(x\in \mathbb {N^*},k\in \mathbb{N}) $, satisfying:

$$ f_k(x)=\sum_{i=0}^{k}S_i(x) $$

Qing Feng gave this function to Ming Yue, who confidently input the function into the geometry board, but the displayed image made him dizzy. To explore the properties of this function, Ming Yue found you.

Given $ k $, for each query, you are given $ m $, and you need to find the number of common points between the graphs of $ y=f_k(x) $ and $ y=m $. It can be proven that this number is always finite.
inputFormat:
The first line contains two integers $ T,k $, indicating there are $ T $ queries, and the meaning of $ k $ is as described in the problem.

Next, there are $ T $ lines, each containing a positive integer, where the $ i $-th line represents the $ m $ for the $ i $-th query.
outputFormat: For each query, output the number of common points.
hint:
**【Sample 1 Explanation】**

For sample $ 1 $, the sets of all common points' $ x $ coordinates for each data set are $ \{12\} $, $ \{5\} $, $ \varnothing $, and $ \{26\} $ respectively.

**【Data Scale and Agreement】**

**This problem uses bundled tests.**

For each test point, $ 1 \le T \le 10^5 $, $ 0 \le k \le 10^9 $, $ 1 \le m \le 10^{18} $.

* Subtask 1 (5 pts): $ k=0 $.
* Subtask 2 (20 pts): $ T \le 10 $, $ m \le 10^5 $, $ k \le 10 $.
* Subtask 3 (25 pts): $ T \le 10 $, $ m \le 10^6 $, $ k \le 10^4 $.
* Subtask 4 (25 pts): $ k \le 1 $.
* Subtask 5 (25 pts): No additional constraints.

title: 巅峰手速
background:
"Little sister, today it's your turn to do the housework..."

Longya brother thus voluntarily experienced a game custom-made for him by Awei, pushing the fate of doing housework onto the gambling table——
description: Awei gave Longya brother $n$ cards, which have been neatly arranged on the table. The number on the $i$-th card from left to right is $a_i$. Longya brother needs to perform a series of operations to make the numbers on the cards non-decreasing from left to right. In each operation, he can extract the $k$-th card from left to right (where $k$ is a given constant) and place it to the far left or far right of these cards. Please help Longya determine whether it's possible to achieve the goal. If possible, also provide him with a relatively simple operation plan.
inputFormat:
First, input an integer $T$, representing the number of test cases.

For each test case, input two lines:

The first line contains two integers $n,k$, representing the number of cards and the given constant.

The second line contains $n$ integers, where the $i$-th integer represents the number $a_i$ on the $i$-th card.
outputFormat:
For each test case, output several lines as follows:

- If Longya cannot achieve the goal, output a single line `No`.

- If he can achieve the goal, first output a line `Yes`, followed by several lines in the format `l c` or `r c`, indicating that he performed `c` consecutive operations of moving the $k$-th card to the far left or far right. Finally, output a line `o` to indicate the end of operations.

Your score will be related to the **number of lines in the operation plan** (not the **number of operations**). (See **scoring method** for details)
samples:
Yes
l 1
r 1
l 1
o
No
No
Yes
o
Yes
r 1
l 1
o
hint:
### Sample Explanation

For the first sample:

Move the second card ($2$) to the far left, changing the card numbers to $2,3,1$.
Move the second card ($3$) to the far right, changing the card numbers to $2,1,3$.
Move the second card ($1$) to the far left, changing the card numbers to $1,2,3$.

At this point, the numbers on the cards are non-decreasing, and the operations end.

### Scoring Method

In a test case, correctly judging whether a solution exists earns $20\%$ of the points. If the operation plan is also correct, the score will be determined based on the number of lines in the operation plan (excluding the last line `o`) according to the following table.

| Lines | Score |
| :-----------: | :-----------: |
| $>7n$ | $40\%$ |
| $\le7n$ | $60\%$ |
| $\le5n$ | $80\%$ |
| $\le3n$ | $100\%$ |

The score for a test point is the minimum score among all test cases.

### Notes

For convenience in debugging, this problem provides a checker for local self-testing. The checker's usage is described later. Note that the provided checker may differ from the actual one used. We guarantee that the actual checker will not exceed 500ms when the number of operation lines does not exceed $7n$.

If the output format is incorrect, you will receive $0$ points. Therefore, if you can judge the existence of a solution but cannot provide an operation plan, you still need to output a line `o` to indicate the end of operations.

To avoid meaningless repeated operations, you must ensure that each operation has $1\leq c \leq n$, otherwise you will receive $0$ points.

### Checker Usage

Download the files `testlib.h` and `checker.cpp` and place them in the same folder. Compile by running `g++ checker.cpp -o checker -std=c++14` to get the executable `checker.exe` (Windows) or `checker` (Linux).

Assume the self-test input is `in.txt`, the program output is `out.txt`. Since the checker cannot judge the existence of a solution, you need to create an answer file (e.g., `ans.txt`) and write the solution existence for each test case line by line. For the sample, the answer file should be:

```plain
Yes
No
No
Yes
Yes
```

Place the input, output, and answer files in the same folder as the compiled checker executable.

- For Windows Powershell, run `.\checker.exe in.txt out.txt ans.txt`.

- For Linux terminal, run `./checker in.txt out.txt ans.txt`.

The checker has three possible outputs: `wrong answer` / `ok` / `points x`, indicating no points / full points / a score ratio of `x` for the test point.

### Data Scale and Constraints

**This problem uses bundled testing with all reasonable subtask dependencies enabled**

For $100\%$ of the data, $1\le T\le10^5$, $1\le k\le n\le 2\times10^5$, $\sum n\le5\times10^{5}$, $1\le a_i\le 10^9$.

For different subtasks, the constraints are as follows:

| Subtask No.	| $n$ | $k$ | Subtask Score |
| :----------: | :----------: | :----------: | :----------: |
| $1$ | $=5$ | $\in[1,n]$ | $10$ |
| $2$ | $\le200$ | $\in[1,n]$ | $40$ |
| $3$ | $\le2\times10^5$ | $=2$ | $20$ |
| $4$ | $\le2\times10^5$ | $\in[1,n]$ | $30$ |

title: 檐牙覆雪
background:
**To avoid frequent timeouts, the time limit for this problem is set to 2 times the competition duration.**

"Rain falls on the window ledge, descending step by step."

But this time it's snow! Tianyi and Aqiu lean by the window, admiring the rare snowfall.
description:
It's a familiar scene: there are a total of $n$ window ledges, numbered from top to bottom, with the highest level numbered as $1$ and the lowest as $n$. Tianyi notices that the snow accumulation on each window ledge can be viewed as a weighted set containing several snow clusters. Initially, the $1$st level window ledge has one snow cluster with a volume of $1$, while other ledges have no snow. Suddenly, a gust of wind carrying snow blows by, causing $n$ transformations in an instant—

In the $i$-th transformation, **every cluster** of snow on the $i$-th level window ledge is swept up. Due to a peculiar physical phenomenon, all window ledges whose numbers are integer multiples of $i$ (**excluding** $i$ itself) will receive new snow accumulations. Specifically, if a swept snow cluster has a volume of $V$, then among the aforementioned window ledges, the one with the largest number will receive a snow cluster with a volume of $V+1$, the next largest will receive a cluster of $V+2$, and so on. Finally, the swept snow clusters mysteriously return to the $i$-th level window ledge, meaning that after this transformation, the snow accumulation on the $i$-th level window ledge remains unchanged.

Aqiu knows Tianyi is curious: after $n$ transformations, what is the total volume of the **largest cluster** on each window ledge? Since they're quietly enjoying the snow, it's up to you to answer this question!
inputFormat:
The first line contains an integer $T$, representing the number of test cases.

The $1$st level window ledge has a snow cluster with volume $1$;

The sum of the maximum volumes is $1+5+4+6+2=18$.

title: 「FAOI-R4」说好的幸福呢
background:
**UPD: Data has been strengthened.**


------------


![](bilibili:BV1fx411N7bU?page=111)
description:
Little M has a permutation $a$ of length $n$.

For a sequence $b$ of length $k$, Little M can perform the following operation:
- Choose a position $i$ where $1\leq i\leq k$, and change the sequence to $[b_i,b_{i+1},\cdots,b_{k},b_{1},b_{2},\cdots,b_{i-2},b_{i-1}]$. In other words, move a suffix of $b$ to the beginning.

Define the value $f(b)$ of sequence $b$ as the “minimum number of operations required to turn $b$ into a strictly increasing sequence”. If it is impossible to turn $b$ into a strictly increasing sequence through operations, then $f(b)=0$.

You need to calculate $\sum\limits_{l=1}^{n}\sum\limits_{r=l}^{n}f([a_{l},a_{l+1},\cdots,a_{r-1},a_{r}])$, which is the sum of the values of all substrings of $a$.
inputFormat:
The first line contains a positive integer $T$ representing the number of test cases.

For each test case:
- The first line contains a positive integer $n$ representing the length of the permutation.
- The second line contains a permutation $a$ of length $n$.
outputFormat: Output $T$ lines, where the $i$-th line contains an integer representing the answer for the $i$-th test case.

title: 「FAOI-R4」手写的从前
description:
Little $ \zeta $ likes non-negative integer powers of $ 2 $.

Please construct a sequence that satisfies the following conditions:
- Its length is a non-negative integer power of $ 2 $;
- The sum of its elements is a given $ m $;
- And each element in the sequence is a non-negative integer power of $ 2 $.

This is too simple, so you also need to make the length of this sequence as small as possible, and on this basis, minimize its lexicographical order.

It can be proven that this problem always has a solution under the given data range.
inputFormat:
The first line contains an integer $ T $, representing the number of test cases.

Next $ T $ lines, each line contains an integer $ m $, representing the sum of the elements in the sequence.
outputFormat: For each test case, output one line with several integers representing the sequence you constructed, separated by spaces. Ensure that the total length of all answer sequences does not exceed $2\times10^6$.
hint:
#### Sample Explanation #1

$ 1, 2, 4 $ are all non-negative integer powers of $ 2 $.

The sequence $[1, 4]$ contains elements that are all non-negative integer powers of $2$, its sum is $1 + 4 = 5 = m$, and its length $2$ is also a non-negative integer power of $2$.

It can be proven that there is no answer with a smaller length or a smaller lexicographical order, so the answer is $[1, 4]$. The same applies to $m=6$.

#### Data Scale and Constraints

| Test Case No. | $ T \le $ | $ m \le $ |
|:-:|:-:|:-:|
| $ 1 $ | $ 1 $ | $ 1 $ |
| $ 2 $ | $ 10 $ | $ 10 $ |
| $ 3 \sim 6 $ | $ 10 $ | $ 10^5 $ |
| $ 7 \sim 8 $ | $ 10^4 $ | $ 10^9 $ |
| $ 9 \sim 10 $ | $ 10^4 $ | $ 10^{18} $ |

For all data, $ 1 \le T \le 10^4 $, $ 1 \le m \le 10^{18} $, ensure that the total length of all answer sequences does not exceed $2\times10^6$. Each test case is worth $10$ points.

title: 歌唱练习
background:
In the year 2077, the much-anticipated Tianyi v100 voice library was released!

However, familiarizing oneself with this new voice library is no easy task.
description:
Tianyi has established a practice plan lasting $n$ days. Tianyi is very diligent; her daily practice duration must be **non-decreasing**. At the same time, to protect her throat, on the $i$-th day, she can practice **at most** $t_i$ units of time. The effectiveness of practice varies each day due to factors like weather, quantified by $w_i$ for the $i$-th day, representing the increase in her familiarity per unit of practice time on that day. Note that $w_i<0$ is also possible, perhaps because the hotter it gets, the worse she performs.

Now, Tianyi has already checked the weather forecast for the $n$ days and estimated the $t_i$ and $w_i$ for each day. Please determine the maximum amount she can increase her familiarity?
inputFormat:
The first line contains an integer $n$, representing the number of days in Tianyi's practice plan.

The second line contains $n$ integers, the $i$-th integer being $t_i$, indicating the maximum practice duration Tianyi cannot exceed on the $i$-th day.

The third line contains $n$ integers, the $i$-th integer being $w_i$, representing the increase in Tianyi's familiarity per unit of practice time on the $i$-th day.
outputFormat: Output one line containing an integer, representing the maximum amount Tianyi can increase her familiarity.
hint:
### Sample Explanation
On the $1$st day, practice for $2$ units of time, increasing familiarity by $4$;  
On the $2$nd day, practice for $2$ units of time, increasing familiarity by $-2$ (decreasing by $2$);  
On the $3$rd day, practice for $3$ units of time, increasing familiarity by $3$.  
Tianyi's total familiarity increased by $5$.

It can be proven that there is no better choice than the above scheme.

### Data Scale and Constraints

**This problem uses bundled tests.** Only when you pass all the test cases for a subtask can you obtain the score for that subtask.

For $100\%$ of the data, $1\le n\le10^6$, $0\le t_i\le10^9$, $-1000\le w_i\le1000$.

For different subtasks, the following constraints apply:

|Subtask No.|$n\le$|$t_i\le$|Special Properties|Subtask Score|
|:-:|:-:|:-:|:-:|:-:|
|$1$|$15$|$15$|None|$10$|
|$2$|$15$|$10^9$|None|$10$|
|$3$|$100$|$100$|None|$10$|
|$4$|$5000$|$5000$|None|$10$|
|$5$|$5000$|$10^9$|None|$10$|
|$6$|$10^5$|$10^5$|None|$10$|
|$7$|$10^6$|$1$|None|$5$|
|$8$|$10^6$|$10^9$|Yes|$15$|
|$9$|$10^6$|$10^9$|None|$20$|

Special Properties: It is guaranteed that $t_i$ is uniformly randomly generated within $[0,10^9]$.

title: 「HCOI-R2」DataErr0r
background:
![](https://cdn.luogu.com.cn/upload/image_hosting/7mafbnqx.png?x-oss-process=image/resize,m_lfit,h_340,w_450)

> How do you know you are not a Program?
description:
Little N has two binary strings $S$ and $T$ with lengths $N$ and $N+1$ respectively. You can perform some modifications on $T$.

- Choose $1\leq i \leq |T|$, delete $T_i$, and shift the remaining characters' indices to the left.
- Choose $1\leq l\leq r\leq |T|$, for all $l\leq i\leq r$ where $(l+i)\equiv 0\pmod 2$, perform $T_i\gets T_i\oplus 1$.

Little N wants to make $T = S$, but she is very lazy, so you need to minimize the number of operations.

**Note: You only need to output this minimized number of operations, without providing the construction.**
inputFormat:
**This problem contains multiple test cases.**

The first line contains a positive integer $K$ indicating the number of test cases.

For each test case, the first line contains a positive integer $N$ as described in the problem statement.

The second line is the binary string $T$, consisting of $N+1$ characters ('0' or '1'), with no spaces between characters.

The third line is the binary string $S$, consisting of $N$ characters ('0' or '1'), with no spaces between characters.
outputFormat: Output $K$ lines, each containing one integer representing the answer for the corresponding test case.
hint:
### Sample Explanation 1
- $1\textbf 01\textbf 01\to 1\textbf11\textbf11$
- $111\underline{1}\to 111$

Using $2$ steps.

### Data Scale and Constraints

**This problem uses bundled tests.**

- Subtask 0 (15pts): $1\leq \sum N\leq 10$.
- Subtask 1 (35pts): $1\leq \sum N\leq 10^3$.
- Subtask 2 (50pts): No additional constraints.

For all data, $1\leq K\leq 1000$, $1\leq \sum N\leq 10^6$, $1\leq N\le 10^6$.

title: [语言月赛 202502] 积木重合
description:
We divide a three-dimensional space into several $1 \times 1 \times 1$ small cubes. We use $(i, j, k)$ to represent the small cube space that is the $i$-th from left to right, the $j$-th from front to back, and the $k$-th from bottom to top.

In this three-dimensional space, two rectangular prisms (including cubes) are given. For each prism, we are given six positive integers $(a _ i, a _ j, a _ k), (b _ i, b _ j, b _ k)$, representing that this prism is composed of small cube spaces from the $a _ i$-th to the $b _ i$-th from left to right, from the $a _ j$-th to the $b _ j$-th from front to back, and from the $a _ k$-th to the $b_ k$-th from bottom to top.

For these two prisms, you need to determine whether they overlap (i.e., whether they share some small cubes). If they do, you also need to determine how many small cubes they share.
inputFormat: The input consists of two lines, each containing six integers $a _ i , a _ j, a _ k, b _ i, b _ j, b _ k$, representing the first prism and the second prism respectively.
outputFormat: Output a single integer representing the number of small cubes shared by the two prisms. If they do not overlap, output $0$.
hint:
### Sample 1 Explanation

The two prisms share and only share $1$ small cube located at $(2, 2, 2)$.

### Data Scale and Constraints

For $100\%$ of the data, $1 \leq a _ i, a _ j , a _ k, b _ i, b _ j, b _ k \leq 10 ^ 6$, $a _ i \leq b _ i$, $a _ j \leq b _ j$, $a _ k \leq b _ k$.

Let $C = \max \{ a _ i, a _ j , a _ k, b _ i, b _ j, b _ k \}$,

| Test Case Number | $C \leq$ | Special Constraints |

| $1$ | $1$ | None |
| $2$ | $2$ | None |
| $3 \sim 8$ | $100$ | None |
| $9 \sim 10$ | $500$ | $a _ i = b _ i$, $a _ j = b _ j$, $a _ k = b _ k$ |
| $11 \sim 13$ | $500$ | None |

title: 调的啥啊
background:
**To avoid frequent timeouts, the time limit for this problem is twice that of the competition.**

Have you ever tried using a laptop touchpad to adjust musical notes?

A-Sheng is currently playing Tianyi—the latest X Studio voice bank. Due to the mysterious disappearance of the touchpad and mouse, every time she adjusts a note, it takes an enormous amount of effort...
description:
In the sequence A-Sheng is currently adjusting, there are a total of $n$ notes. From left to right, the pitch of the $i$-th note is $s_i$. A-Sheng finds that three notes $s_i,s_j,s_k~(1\le i<j<k\le n)$ produce an unpleasant auditory sensation. She decides to adjust them to $s_i',s_j',s_k'$ such that $s_i'\le s_k'$ and $s_j'\le s_k'$. Adjusting the touchpad is really exhausting:

- Adjusting $s_i$ to $s_i'$ costs A-Sheng $a\times|s_i-s_i'|$ effort;
- Adjusting $s_j$ to $s_j'$ costs A-Sheng $b\times|s_j-s_j'|$ effort;
- Adjusting $s_k$ to $s_k'$ costs A-Sheng $c\times|s_k-s_k'|$ effort.

Thus, the total effort A-Sheng spends to adjust these three notes is:
$$
z=a\cdot|s_i-s_i'|+b\cdot|s_j-s_j'|+c\cdot|s_k-s_k'|.
$$

A-Sheng will naturally find the $(s_i',s_j',s_k')$ that minimizes $z$, and we denote this minimum $z$ as $f(i,j,k)$. Now, A-Sheng wants to know, for all $(i,j,k)$ satisfying $i<j<k$, what is the sum of $f(i,j,k)$? You only need to provide her with the answer modulo $2^{32}$.
inputFormat:
The first line contains an integer $n$ representing the length of the note sequence.

The second line contains three integers $a$, $b$, $c$.

The third line contains $n$ integers representing the sequence $s$, which are the pitches of each note.
outputFormat: Output a single integer as the answer.
hint:
### Sample Explanation

$f(1,2,3)=4$, where one optimal $(s_i',s_j',s_k')$ is $(2,3,3)$.

$f(1,2,4)=13$, where one optimal $(s_i',s_j',s_k')$ is $(2,2,2)$.

$f(1,3,4)=9$, where one optimal $(s_i',s_j',s_k')$ is $(2,2,2)$.

$f(2,3,4)=13$, where one optimal $(s_i',s_j',s_k')$ is $(3,3,3)$.

The sum of $f(i,j,k)$ is $4+13+9+13=39$.

### Data Scale and Constraints

**This problem uses bundled tests.** You will only receive points for this subtask if you pass all test cases.

For $100\%$ of the data, $3\le n\le5\times10^5$, $1\le s_i,a,b,c\le 10^9$.

For different subtasks, the following constraints apply:

| Subtask No.	| $n$ | Special Properties | Subtask Points |
| :----------: | :----------: | :----------: | :----------: |
| $1$ | $=3$ | None | $5$ |
| $2$ | $\le300$ | None | $5$ |
| $3$ | $\le1000$ | None | $10$ |
| $4$ | $\le5\times10^3$ | None | $20$ |
| $5$ | $\le5\times10^4$ | None | $20$ |
| $6$ | $\le5\times10^5$ | Yes | $20$ |
| $7$ | $\le5\times10^5$ | None | $20$ |

Special Properties: The number of distinct pitches does not exceed $10$.

title: 扶苏出勤日记
description:
Fusu is a dance game enthusiast. In the next $n$ days, she will play the dance game every day, and she hopes to **play the same number of rounds each day**.

Playing one round of the dance game costs $1$ game coin. However, the price of game coins may change every day. Specifically, on the $i$-th day, one yuan can buy $a_i$ game coins.

By working for Luogu~~black~~ labor, Fusu earns some income every day. She will earn $b_i$ yuan on the $i$-th day.

Each day, Fusu will **first** receive the day's income $b_i$ yuan, then buy game coins, and then play the dance game.

Fusu can use any amount of her money to buy game coins at the day's exchange rate. That is, she doesn't have to exchange all her money at once; she can use only part of her money to buy game coins on that day and save the rest for future days. Similarly, she doesn't have to spend all her game coins in one day; she can spend only part of her game coins on that day and save the rest for future days.

Fusu knows the coin prices and her daily income for the next $n$ days. She wants to play the same number of rounds of the dance game each day in the next $n$ days. Therefore, she wants to know, under the optimal strategy for buying game coins, what is the maximum number of rounds she can play each day?
inputFormat:
**This problem contains multiple test cases within a single test point**. The first line is a positive integer $T$, representing the number of test cases. For each test case:

The first line is an integer $n$, representing the total number of days.  
The second line contains $n$ integers $a_1, a_2, \dots ,a_n$, representing the number of coins that can be bought with one yuan each day.  
The third line contains $n$ integers $b_1, b_2, \dots ,b_n$, representing Fusu's daily income.
outputFormat: For each test case, output one line with an integer representing the answer.

title: 「HCOI-R2」哀之距
background:
A cat with stripes horizontal and vertical? Have you encountered it?

Meow...meow.

------------

It's unclear in what mental state the problem setter was when writing this problem background, but I hope he can win the revival round and return to OI.
description:
The cat encountered by Sorrow can be seen as a plane with $n$ rectangles on it.

The bottom-left corner of the $i$-th rectangle is at $(x_{i,0},y_{i,0})$, and the top-right corner is at $(x_{i,1},y_{i,1})$.

Find the maximum distance between any two rectangles.

The distance between two rectangles is defined as the minimum Chebyshev distance between any two points, one from each rectangle (including the edges).

**Chebyshev distance: The Chebyshev distance between $(a,b)$ and $(c,d)$ is $\max(|a-c|,|b-d|)$.**
inputFormat:
The first line contains an integer $n$, representing the number of rectangles.

The next $n$ lines each contain four integers $x_{i,0}, y_{i,0}, x_{i,1}, y_{i,1}$, representing the $i$-th rectangle.
outputFormat: Output a single integer, representing the maximum distance between any two rectangles.
hint:
### Data Scale and Constraints

**This problem uses bundled tests.**
+ Subtask 0 (10 pts): $n \leq 20$, $x_{i,0}, y_{i,0}, x_{i,1}, y_{i,1} \le 20$.
+ Subtask 1 (15 pts): $n \leq 10^3$.
+ Subtask 2 (20 pts): $x_{i,0} = x_{i,1}, y_{i,0} = y_{i,1}$.
+ Subtask 3 (55 pts): No additional constraints.

For all data, $2 \le n \le 2 \times 10^5 $, $0 \le x_{i,0} \le x_{i,1} \le 10^{18}$, $0 \le y_{i,0} \le y_{i,1} \le 10^{18}$.

title: 「HCOI-R2」光影
background:
There is a dark corner in my heart,

That is the territory of night, my hometown,

I will, like many, many others,

Return to that pure place,

Even if darkness is nothing to fear.
description:
Given a binary string of length $n$, you need to delete $k$ `0`s from it.

The longest consecutive sequence of the same digit is called a "block". Find the minimum number of `1` blocks that can be achieved.
inputFormat:
The first line contains two integers $n,k$.

The second line contains a binary string of length $n$.
outputFormat: A number representing the minimum number of `1` blocks that can be achieved.
hint:
### Sample Explanation 1
Delete `0`s at positions $2,7$.

### Data Scale and Constraints

+ Subtask 0 (25 pts): $n\leq10^4$.
+ Subtask 1 (10 pts): $e\leq10$.
+ Subtask 2 (65 pts): No additional constraints.

$e$ represents the count of `0`s in the binary string.

For all data, $1\leq k\leq e\leq n\leq10^7$.

title: 「FAOI-R9」决战黎明
background:
Laoguang is a person who is very good at inventing small games.

Qingfeng likes to play chess with Mingyue. One day, he played a game invented by Laoguang called "The Chess Battle of Dawn". Because the game was so fun, he couldn't stop playing, but unfortunately, Mingyue was too smart and always bullied him. So, he decided to pass this problem to you and let you help him study it.
description:
Some definitions are as follows:

* Battle line: The track on which the chess pieces are arranged according to the order given by the player. **Once a chess piece enters a battle line, it must move on this battle line.**

* Chess piece level: The level assigned to a chess piece by the player, which will and will only change due to the result of a "battle". **Initially, this level must be a positive integer.**

* Battle: For a battle between two chess pieces, when the chess pieces have the same level, both pieces are eliminated; when the two chess pieces have different levels, the level of the higher-level piece decreases by $1$, and the lower-level piece is eliminated. In one battle, at least $1$ chess piece will be eliminated.

The game process is as follows:

* Initially, both players have a score of $0$.

* **Preparation phase**: Both players specify the number of their chess pieces, the level of each chess piece, the battle line it belongs to, and the order of appearance. **Note that it is possible to not place any chess pieces on a certain battle line.**

* **Battle phase**: For each battle line, the following process is performed (note that "chess pieces on the field" here refers to the chess pieces **on this battle line** that have not been eliminated):

  * If neither side has chess pieces on the field, the process for this battle line ends.

  * If one side no longer has chess pieces on the field, the other side gains game points equal to the sum of the levels of the chess pieces on the field, and the process for this battle line ends.
  
  * If both sides have chess pieces on the field, the chess pieces from both sides with the earliest appearance order engage in one "battle".

* **Settlement phase**: After the processes for all battle lines end, the game scores of the two players are the result of this game.

In this game, there are $n$ battle lines.

Mingyue has already completed her preparation phase, but Qingfeng secretly saw all of Mingyue's $n$ battle line preparation plans before he finished his own preparation.

Please help Qingfeng design a preparation plan where all his chess pieces have initial levels as positive integers and their sum does not exceed $m$, and after the game ends, Mingyue's game score is minimized. You only need to output this minimum score.

Because Qingfeng loves to play, you need to provide answers for $T$ independent games.
inputFormat:
The first line contains two integers $T,n$, representing the number of test cases and the number of battle lines in each game.

For each test case:

The first line contains an integer $m$, representing the upper limit of the sum of Qingfeng's chess piece levels in this game.

Then follow $n$ lines, the $i$-th line starts with an integer $l_i$, representing the number of chess pieces Mingyue has placed on this battle line, followed by $l_i$ integers, representing the levels of each chess piece Mingyue has deployed in order of appearance (the order of the $l_i$ chess pieces is their appearance order).
outputFormat: For each test case, output one line with an integer, representing the answer required by the problem.
hint:
**【Sample 1 Explanation】**

For the first test case, one possible solution is Qingfeng deploying one chess piece with an initial level of $2$.

The battle process is as follows:

* Qingfeng's on-field chess piece levels are $\{2\}$, Mingyue's on-field chess piece levels are $\{1,1\}$. Qingfeng's level $2$ chess piece battles Mingyue's level $1$ chess piece, Mingyue's piece is eliminated, and Qingfeng's piece level decreases to $1$.

* Qingfeng's on-field chess piece levels are $\{1\}$, Mingyue's on-field chess piece levels are $\{1\}$. Both sides deploy level $1$ chess pieces to battle, and both are eliminated.

* Neither side has chess pieces left, this battle line does not affect the scores.

Therefore, Mingyue's score in this solution is $0$.

**【Data Scale and Agreement】**

**This problem uses bundled tests.**

For each test point:

* $1 \le T \le 5$;

* $\bm{1 \le n \le 2}$, $1 \le l_i \le 10^5$;

* $0 \le m \le 10^{18}$, Mingyue's chess piece levels are positive integers not exceeding $10^9$.

| Subtask No. | $n$ | $l_i$ | $m$ | Mingyue's Chess Piece Level Upper Limit | Points |
|:-:|:-:|:-:|:-:|:-:|:-:|
| $1$ | $=1$ | $\le 5$ | $\le 10$ | $\le 5$ | $8$ |
| $2$ | $=1$ | $\le 300$ | $\le 300$ | $\le 5$ | $16$ |
| $3$ | $=1$ | - | - | $=1$ | $4$ |
| $4$ | $=1$ | - | - | - | $24$ |
| $5$ | $=2$ | - | $=0$ | - | $4$ |
| $6$ | $=2$ | $\le 300$ | - | - | $8$ |
| $7$ | $=2$ | $\le 5000$ | - | - | $12$ |
| $8$ | $=2$ | - | - | - | $24$ |

title: 「FAOI-R4」问题跳转
background:
Welcome to participate in FAOI-R4!

Little M, as the problem setter for Problem A, wants to enter Problem A to check the submissions from contestants. However, Little M doesn't often use Luogu, so he doesn't know how to find Problem A. Quickly, another FAOI team member, Little L, sent Little M the problem number of Problem A, through which Little M can locate Problem A.

But, Little M really doesn't know how to use Luogu—he doesn't even know how to jump to the corresponding problem through the problem number!
description:
Finally, Little M found a feature called "Problem Jump" on the Luogu homepage. By entering the problem number in the input box, one can jump to the corresponding problem. The problem's URL is `https://www.luogu.com.cn/problem/<PID>`, where `<PID>` is the problem number input by the user.

Luogu's problem numbers follow special rules:
- The first character can only be one of `PBCASUT`, and all characters are visible ASCII characters within the range [33,126].
- Problem numbers starting with `P` are "Main Problem Library Problems", which consist of `P` followed by a string of digits, such as `P1145` and `P10000`.

When the user inputs a problem number that is a "Main Problem Library Problem", the leading `P` can be omitted. For example, inputting `1001` can jump to P1001.

Given the problem number input by Little M, please output the corresponding URL.
inputFormat:
The first line contains an integer $T$, representing the number of test cases.

For each test case, input one line with a string, representing the problem number input by Little M.
outputFormat: For each test case, output one line with a string, representing the URL of the corresponding problem.
samples:
https://www.luogu.com.cn/problem/P1001
https://www.luogu.com.cn/problem/P1234
https://www.luogu.com.cn/problem/B2027
https://www.luogu.com.cn/problem/U76533
https://www.luogu.com.cn/problem/T512682
https://www.luogu.com.cn/problem/CF10A
https://www.luogu.com.cn/problem/AT_abc114_d
https://www.luogu.com.cn/problem/SP11470
https://www.luogu.com.cn/problem/UVA13277
hint:
#### 【Sample Explanation】

For the first test case, `1001` is actually `P1001` with the leading `P` omitted, so the output should be `https://www.luogu.com.cn/problem/P1001`.

title: 三叉求和
background: Long, long ago, little A was picking apples on an infinitely deep ternary tree. This apple tree's root has no apples, and the number of apples at each of a node's three children is three times the number of apples at that node plus $0,1,2$ respectively. Little A walked exactly $d$ steps down from the root and picked $k$ apples. Unfortunately, little A only remembers certain digits of $k$ in its ternary representation. He wants to know how many possible ways there are that match his memory.
description:
There is an infinitely deep ternary tree rooted at $0$, where the children of node $i$ are nodes $3i+1, 3i+2, 3i+3$ respectively.

Let the weight of node $i$ be $a_i$. For $0\le j\le 2$, $a_{3i+j+1}=3\times a_i+j$, and specifically, $a_0=0$.

Your task is to find all simple paths starting from the root with length $=d$ such that the sum of the weights of all nodes on the path equals $k$. You need to count the number of such valid paths.

However, $k$ is not unique. Only certain digits of $k$ in its ternary representation are known, while the others are represented by the character $\tt ?$. You need to sum the answers for all possible $k$ in the above problem and then take the modulo $10^9+7$.
inputFormat:
The first line contains an integer $d$.

The second line contains a string of length $d$, representing $k$ in ternary form. Note that $k$ may have leading zeros.
outputFormat: Output a single integer representing your answer.
hint:
### Sample #1 Explanation

Valid paths are:
- $[0,1,5,17]$
- $[0,2,7,23]$
- $[0,2,9,30]$

The corresponding node weights are:

- $[0,0,1,4]$
- $[0,1,3,10]$
- $[0,1,5,17]$
### Data Range
|Test Case No.|$d$|Special Properties|
|:----:|:----:|:----:|
|$1\sim 2$|$\leq15$|-|
|$3$|$\leq50$|A|
|$4$|$\leq50$|B|
|$5\sim 8$|$\leq50$|-|
|$9\sim 10$|$\leq300$|A|
|$11\sim 12$|$\leq300$|B|
|$13\sim 14$|$\leq300$|-|
|$15$|$\leq2000$|A|
|$16$|$\leq2000$|B|
|$17\sim 20$|$\leq2000$|-|

Special Property A: Guarantees that the number of $?$ in $k$ is $\leq 1$.

Special Property B: Guarantees that all positions are $?$.

For $100\%$ of the data, $1\le d\le 2000,0\le k\lt 3^{d+1}$.

title: 「HCOI-R2」巡回演出
background: Little A is a famous singer in HCOI country, and she plans to hold a concert tour.
description:
HCOI country consists of $n$ cities, which can be abstracted as a rooted tree with $n$ nodes, where the capital is the root $r$. Little A plans to start from $r$ and traverse the entire country for her performance.

Specifically, let $x$ be Little A's current position, and record a sequence $s$:
- Initially, $x=r$, $s=[r]$.
- If $x$ has unvisited children, arbitrarily choose one child $y$, append $y$ to the end of $s$, and move to $y$.
- If no such $y$ exists: if $x=r$, the performance ends; otherwise, move to $x$'s parent.

We call the final $s$ obtained as a **traversal method** of $T$, and different choices of children can yield multiple traversal methods. It can be observed that a traversal method is essentially a DFS order of $T$.

Little A's assistant provides a fee table $\{w_{n-1}\}$, and the income $w(T,s)$ of this concert tour can be calculated as follows:
- For $i\in[1,n]$, Little A passes through the nodes on the simple path from $s_{i}$ to $s_{i\bmod n+1}$ in $T$ (**excluding** $s_{i}$ but **including** $s_{i\bmod n+1}$).
- Each time she reaches a node, if it's the $i$-th visit, Little A receives $w_i$ coins as payment.
- $w(T,s)$ is the total number of coins Little A receives.

Little A's assistant also provides the traversal method $\{s_n\}$ for this performance. A tree $T$ is defined as valid if and only if $\{s_n\}$ is one of its **traversal methods**. You need to calculate the sum of $w(T,s)$ for all distinct valid $T$, modulo $998244353$.

Two rooted trees $T$ and $T'$ are considered different if and only if they have different roots or there exists an edge present in $T$ but not in $T'$.
inputFormat:
**This problem contains multiple test cases.**

The first line contains a positive integer $T$ representing the number of test cases. For each test case:

The first line contains a positive integer $n$, representing the number of cities in HCOI country.

The second line contains $n$ positive integers $s_1,s_2,\cdots,s_n$, representing Little A's traversal method for this performance.

The third line contains $n-1$ non-negative integers $w_1,w_2,\cdots,w_{n-1}$, representing the fee table for the performance.
outputFormat: For each test case, output one line containing an integer representing the sum of $w(T,s)$ for all valid $T$, modulo $998244353$.
hint:
#### Sample Explanation #1

Below, we use $(r,E)$ to represent a rooted tree, where $E$ is the edge set and $r$ is the root.

For the first test case, the only valid $T$ is $(1,\{(1,2)\})$. Little A passes through two paths $1\to 2$ and $2\to 1$, visiting $1$ and $2$ once each, so the answer is $1+1=2$.

For the second test case, the valid $T$ are $(1,\{(1,2),(2,3)\})$ and $(1,\{(1,2),(2,3)\})$, with $w(T,s)=5$ for both, so the answer is $5+5=10$.

For the third test case, the valid $T$ are $(1,\{(1,2),(1,3),(1,4)\})$, $(1,\{(1,2),(1,3),(3,4)\})$, $(1,\{(1,2),(2,3),(1,4)\})$, $(1,\{(1,2),(2,3),(2,4)\})$, and $(1,\{(1,2),(2,3),(3,4)\})$, with $w(T,s)$ being $9,8,8,9,8$ respectively, so the answer is $9+8+8+9+8=42$.

For the fourth test case, one valid $T$ is $(1,\{(1,3),(2,4),(3,2),(3,5)\})$, with $w(T,s)=13$.

#### Data Range and Constraints

**This problem uses bundled tests.**

| Subtask No. | $\boldsymbol{n\le}$ | $\boldsymbol{\sum n\le}$ | Special Properties | Points |
| :----------: | :----------: | :----------: | :----------: | :----------: |
| $1$ | $4$ | $10^6$ | A | $5$ |
| $2$ | $8$ | $40$ | A | $15$ |
| $3$ | $12$ | $60$ | None | $10$ |
| $4$ | $50$ | $200$ | None | $10$ |
| $5$ | $100$ | $500$ | None | $10$ |
| $6$ | $10^3$ | $5\times 10^3$ | B | $10$ |
| $7$ | $10^3$ | $5\times 10^3$ | None | $5$ |
| $8$ | $10^5$ | $2\times 10^5$ | B | $5$ |
| $9$ | $10^5$ | $2\times 10^5$ | None | $15$ |
| $10$ | $5\times10^5$ | $10^6$ | None | $15$ |

- Special Property A: $i\in[1,n]$, $s_i=i$.
- Special Property B: $w_1=1$, and for $i\in[2,n-1]$, $w_i=0$.

For all data, $1\le T\le 10^5$, $2\le n\le 5\times10^5$, $\sum n\le 10^6$, $0\le w_i<998244353$, and $\{s_n\}$ is a permutation of $1\sim n$.

title: 求和
description:
Given an integer sequence $a$ of length $n$.

You can perform several operations (possibly zero) on this sequence. Each operation is as follows:

Select indices $i$ and $j$ satisfying $1\le i,j\le n$, assign $a_i$ to $a_i+1$, and simultaneously assign $a_j$ to $a_j-1$. $i$ and $j$ cannot be the same.

Find the minimum number of operations required to make the sum of prefix sums equal to the sum of suffix sums.

That is, let $s_i=a_1+a_2+\dots+a_i,t_i=a_i+a_{i+1}+\dots+a_n$, such that $s_1+s_2+\dots+s_n=t_1+t_2+\dots+t_n$.

Note that $a_i$ can become negative.
inputFormat:
The first line contains an integer $n$.

The second line contains $n$ integers separated by spaces, representing the sequence $a$.
outputFormat:
Output one line with an integer representing the minimum number of operations.

If there is no solution, output $-1$.

title: [语言月赛 202501] 数字谜
description: Given a two-digit number $a$, ask at least how much to add to $a$ (can be $+0$) to make the units digit of $a$ become $b$.
